questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the states of ion channels during the absolute refractory period of an action potential?

choices.text: Both Na+ & K+ channels are closed
Na+ channel closed, K+ channel open
Na+ channel open, K+ channel closed
Na+ channels reset, K+ channels remain open

questions.solution:
During the absolute refractory period, the Na+ channel is closed and the K+ channels are open.

Both channels are closed in the resting phase, while the Na+ channel alone opens in the depolarisation phase.

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in the following sequence:

1. Resting-state: Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the K+ channels remain open and slowly return to the closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her baby to the OPD saying that the baby defecates shortly after every meal. Which of the following GIT hormones amplify this response?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of the baby defecating shortly after every meal is a classic description of the gastrocolic reflex. Gastrin amplifies the gastrocolic reflex.

Distension of the stomach and digestive byproducts in the small intestine activate afferents to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia. This results in stimulation of the colon and an urge to defecate. This is known as the gastrocolic reflex. This reflex is amplified by the action of gastrin.

GIT reflexes which are mediated by prevertebral sympathetic ganglia include:

  • Gastrocolic reflex
  • Enterogastric reflex → signals from the colon and small intestine inhibit stomach motility and secretion
  • Colonoileal reflex → signals from the colon to inhibit the emptying of ileal contents into the colon

GIT reflexes which are mediated by the brain stem and spinal cord include:

  • Pain reflexes that cause inhibition of the whole gastrointestinal tract
  • Long-distance vagal reflexes regulating gastric motor and secretory activity
  • Defecation reflex → Distension of the rectum and colon results in powerful contractions of the rectum, colon, and abdominal wall which are required for defecation.

questions.text: During an experiment to study the functioning of baroreceptors, a participant is asked to forcefully expire against a closed glottis. What physiological change do you expect after the glottis is opened?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a participant performing the Valsalva maneuver and then releasing it. The change which can be expected when a Valsalva maneuver is released is bradycardia. 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and blood vessels including the aortic arch and carotid sinus. The carotid sinus is supplied by a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) and the aortic arch by a branch of the vagus nerve (X CN). Baroreceptors are stimulated by the stretching of the walls of the respective vessels when there is an increased volume or pressure in the vessel. They are important in the immediate management of blood pressure. The pathway of the baroreceptor reflex is given below. 

 

When the person begins straining during a Valsalva maneuver, there will be increased intrathoracic pressure, which will cause a decrease in venous return and cardiac output. This leads to inhibition of the baroreceptors and consequent tachycardia and an increase in peripheral resistance. When the glottis is opened, the intrathoracic pressure and the cardiac output return to normal, but the peripheral vessels are still constricted. This causes the blood pressure to rise above normal. Elevated BP stimulates the baroreceptors and causes bradycardia.

In chronic hypertension, the baroreceptor reflex is reset to maintain higher blood pressure. A long-term change in blood pressure that results from loss of baroreceptor reflex is termed neurogenic hypertension.

  • Increased sympathetic tone

questions.text: A gastrointestinal smooth muscle was being studied. It was then subjected to electrical and mechanical recording. A trace of the recordings obtained is given below. What is the effect of acetylcholine and epinephrine on the number of spikes, respectively?
questions.solution:
Acetylcholine increases and epinephrine decreases the number of spikes and the tension of the gastrointestinal smooth muscle.

The smooth muscles in the gastrointestinal tract have a basal electrical rhythm. The basal electrical rhythm (BER) is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65 mV and -45 mV. The interstitial cells of Cajal initiate this BER. These cells are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features. In the stomach and small intestine, they are located in the outer circular muscle layer near the myenteric plexus, in the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer. The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.

Spike potentials on BER:

The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension. The depolarizing portion of each spike is due to Ca2+ influx, and the repolarizing portion is due to K+ efflux. Important neurotransmitters that affect BER are

  • Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.
  • Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

The function of the BER is to coordinate peristaltic and other motor activity, such as setting the rhythm of segmentation, contractions can occur only during the depolarizing part of the waves. After vagotomy or transection of the stomach wall, for example, peristalsis in the stomach becomes irregular and chaotic.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the bradycardia seen in Cushing reflex?
questions.solution:
The bradycardia seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by baroreceptor activation in response to a raised arterial blood pressure.

The Cushing reflex is a triad of raised arterial blood pressure, bradycardia, and irregular respiration caused by raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Raised ICP compromises blood flow to the brain and activates the rostral ventrolateral medulla with an increase in arterial blood pressure. The increased arterial pressure maintains cerebral perfusion and activates the baroreceptor reflex that causes bradycardia.

The irregular respiration seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by inadequate blood flow and increased pressure on the brainstem.

Bainbridge reflex: It refers to the increase in the heart rate when the atrium is stretched. Whenever there is a stretch of the atrium, the stretch receptors are activated. They transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase the heart rate and strength of heart contraction. This reflex prevents the accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and pulmonary circulation.

J reflex: C fiber-endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. 

Bezold Jarisch reflex (Coronary chemoreflex): Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called the Bezold Jarisch reflex and can be elicited by capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography.

A centre that reduces the desire for food is known as a satiety centre. These centres are sensitive to blood glucose concentration and cause satiety in hyperglycemic states. The hypothalamic areas that regulate satiety are:

questions.text: A young man presents to the ER following a road traffic accident. He has sustained multiple injuries and has lost a lot of blood. Which of the following changes is most likely to be seen in his pulmonary blood flow in a sitting position?

choices.text: No blood flow in the base of the lungs
Intermittent systolic blood flow in the apices of the lungs
No blood flow in the apices of the lungs
Intermittent diastolic blood flow in the base of the lungs

questions.solution:
In a patient who has suffered severe blood loss, there will be zone 1 blood flow in the apices of the lungs. This means that there is no blood flow to the apices at any time during the cardiac cycle.

The blood flow in the upper parts of the lungs is driven by the difference in the pressure in the alveoli (PA) and the pulmonary capillaries (Pa). In a scenario when there is an increase in alveolar air pressure (positive pressure ventilation) or a decrease in alveolar capillary pressure (severe blood loss), the pulmonary capillaries collapse because of the pressure of the alveoli around them. This leads to a cessation of all blood flow in the apices of the lungs, known as zone 1 blood flow.

Here:

Pa - Pulmonary Arterial Pressure

PA - Pulmonary Alveolar Pressure

Pv - Pulmonary Venous Pressure

There are three possible patterns of pulmonary blood flow:

  • In zone 1 there is no blood flow during any portion of the cardiac cycle because the alveolar-capillary pressure is always lower than the alveolar air pressure.
  • In zone 2 there is intermittent blood flow because the systolic pressure in the pulmonary capillaries is greater than the alveolar air pressure, but the diastolic pressure is less than the alveolar air pressure.
  • In zone 3 there is continuous blood flow because the alveolar-capillary pressure remains greater than alveolar air pressure during the entire cardiac cycle.

Normally, the lungs have only zones 2 and 3 blood flow. Zone 2 (intermittent flow) is present in the apices and zone 3 (continuous flow) is present in all the lower areas. However, if there is an increase in alveolar air pressure (positive pressure ventilation) or a decrease in alveolar capillary pressure (severe blood loss), zone 2 can convert into zone 1. During exercise, there is an increased blood flow to all the parts of the lungs, and specifically the lung apices convert from zone 2 to zone 3.

questions.text: During an experiment, it was found that a patient's kidneys consumed 70 mL of oxygen per minute. If the oxygen concentration in renal artery and renal vein is 19 mL/dL of blood and 14 mL/dL of blood respectively, calculate the blood flow across the kidneys.
questions.solution:
Fick principle can be applied in this question to determine the blood flow across the patient's kidneys.  

Blood flow across the organ = Oxygen consumption by the organ / [O2] artery - [O2] vein

Hence blood flow across this patient's kidneys = 70 mL/min / 19-14 mL/dL

                                = 1400 mL/min

Fick principle can also be used to measure the cardiac output because it is blood flow across the whole body. When measuring the cardiac output using this principle, the following formula should be used:

Cardiac output = Oxygen consumption / [O2] pulmonary vein - [O2] pulmonary artery

questions.text:
Given below is a graph of the 24-hour levels of a hormone. Choose the factors which increase its secretion.
  1. Arginine infusion 
  2. Stage IV sleep
  3. Increased free fatty acids in the blood
  4. Ghrelin
  5. REM sleep
questions.solution:
The hormone depicted in the graph shows pulsatile secretion, with an increase during strenuous exercise and early periods of sleep, indicating that it is the growth hormone (GH). Growth hormone secretion is increased by arginine infusion, ghrelin, and deep sleep (stages II and IV) among the given factors.

Growth hormone is secreted from the somatotropes located in the anterior pituitary. The levels of growth hormones show diurnal variation as well as variation across different age groups. Adolescents have the highest circulating levels of growth hormone, followed by children and adults. The levels are relatively low during the day and the pulsatile release of this hormone occurs during sleep.

Important regulators of growth hormone:

  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone stimulates the production of the hormone
  • Somatostatin inhibits the release of GH
  • Ghrelin increases the GH release (statement 4)

Stimuli that increase GH secretion:

  1. Hypoglycemia, deoxyglucose, fasting
  2. Exercise
  3. Infusion of arginine (statement 1)
  4. Protein-rich meal
  5. Glucagon
  6. Deep sleep (stages II and IV) (statement 2)
  7. Estrogens and androgens
  8. Stressful stimuli

Stimuli that decrease GH secretion:

  1. Glucose 
  2. Cortisol
  3. Free fatty acids (statement 3)
  4. Growth hormone and IGF-1
  5. REM sleep (statement 5)
  6. Medroxyprogesterone

GH can act directly on the cells or mediate its actions through insulin-like growth factors (IGF). The functions which are mediated through IGFs are insulin-like activity, anti-lipolytic activity, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth. Direct actions of GH are sodium retention, decreased insulin sensitivity, lipolysis, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth.

questions.text: A young patient started neglecting one-half of his body after an accident. He uses only his right side of the body, trims his beard only on the right side of his face, and reads only the right half of the page. There are no apparent primary visual, auditory, or somatosensory defects. This occurs due to an injury in which of the following parts of the brain?

choices.text: Superior temporal gyrus of the categorical hemisphere
Inferior parietal lobule of the representational hemisphere
Superior part of the hippocampus and mammillary bodies
Angular gyrus of the representational hemisphere

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is neglecting one-half of his body. This is called unilateral inattention and neglect which occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule of the representational hemisphere.

In our human brain, one hemisphere is specialised for sequential-analytic processes (the categorical hemisphere or dominant hemisphere) and another is specialised for visuospatial relations (the representational hemisphere or the non-dominant hemisphere).

Lesions in the representational hemisphere lead to:

  • Astereognosis - the inability to identify objects by feeling them due to a lesion in the parietal lobe
  • Agnosia - inability to recognize objects by a particular sensory modality even though the sensory modality itself is intact. This commonly occurs due to a lesion in the parietal lobe. Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognise faces
  • Unilateral inattention and neglect - Patients neglect one-half of their bodies and may experience personal neglect syndrome. It occurs due to an injury to the inferior parietal lobule and a region of the posterior parietal cortex close to the occipital lobe.

The function of the non-dominant side of the parietal lobe is spatial orientation and constructional skills. Its lesion causes spatial disorientation, constructional apraxia, neglect of the non-dominant side, dressing apraxia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

The somatic sensory area and related parts of the posterior parietal lobe project to the premotor cortex. It is associated with aiming and manipulating the hands at an object and hand-eye coordination. Neurons in this posterior parietal cortex contribute to the descending pathways involved in motor control.

The functions of the dominant hemisphere are logical, analytical, sequential thinking, and verbal tasks, such as math, language forms, and philosophy. In this hemisphere, the parietal lobe is concerned with calculation, language, planned movement, and appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture. A lesion here causes dyscalculia, dysphasia, dyslexia, apraxia, agnosia, and homonymous hemianopia. 

Other options:

Option A: Lesions in the superior temporal gyrus of the categorical hemisphere lead to Wernicke's aphasia. 

Option C: Lesions in the hippocampus, mamillary bodies, nucleus basalis of Meynert, and areas of the forebrain result in memory disturbances.

Option D: Lesions in the angular gyrus of the categorical hemisphere result in anomic aphasia.

questions.text: Compliance of the lung is increased in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Normal aging lungs have increased lung compliance.

Compliance is given as a change in lung volume per unit change in surrounding pressure. It is expressed as compliance = ΔV/ΔP.

The graph shown below explains the change in volume of the lung, as the intrapleural pressure increases.

Here compliance of B>A>C.

Compliance is increased in normal aging lungs and pulmonary emphysema due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (tendency of the lungs to become less stretched).

Compliance is decreased in fibrosis, pulmonary edema, and unventilated lungs due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding the mechanoreceptor involved in sensing steady pressure.
  1. It is a type of phasic receptor. 
  2. It is innervated by type C nerve fibers. 
  3. It is located in the epidermis. 
  4. Its receptor potential exceeds the threshold for a long period of time. 
  5. It has a large receptive field.
questions.solution:
The mechanoreceptor in question which is responsible for sensing sustained touch and pressure is the Merkel cell. Located in the epidermis, they are slow-adapting (tonic) receptors because they can code for stimulus duration. Longer the stimulus duration, longer the duration for which the receptor potential remains above the threshold. 

Merkel cell is a type of slow-adapting (tonic) receptor (statement 1) which projects into the epidermis from the underside. They are seen in the basal layer of the epidermis. It senses sustained touch and pressure. It is innervated by Aβ type of large myelinated nerve fibers (statement 2). Like Meissner corpuscles, they have a small receptive field (statement 5) and provide excellent tactile localization. 

Based on how fast the mechanoreceptors are able to adapt to the sensation, they are divided into:

  • Phasic receptors include the receptors which adapt quickly to a constant stimulus and cannot be used to transmit a continuous signal. They detect primarily the onset, offset, and a change in the stimulus. For example, Pacinian corpuscles and Meissner corpuscles. 
  • Tonic receptors are the ones which adapt slowly. They are able to code for stimulus intensity and duration, resulting in a long series of action potentials. For example, Merkel cells, muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs. 
  • Non-adapting receptors include the nociceptors. 

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: An athlete is preparing for a 100-meter sprint race. Choose the correct statement regarding the type of muscle fibers which would benefit him the most.
questions.solution:
For an athlete preparing for a 100-meter sprint race, the most beneficial type of muscle fibers would be type II or fast-twitch type of muscle fibers. Fast-twitch muscle fibers contain a large amount of glycolytic enzymes and rely predominantly on anaerobic glycolysis for short bursts of energy. 

Skeletal muscle fibers are broadly classified as slow-twitch or type I and fast-twitch or type II muscle fibers. 

      Fast-twitch muscle fibers     Slow-twitch muscle fibers
They are twice as large in diameter when compared with slow-twitch fibers. Their diameter is half as large as compared to fast-twitch fibers.
Over a short duration, they can achieve twice as much maximal power compared to slow-twitch fibers and are organized for power. They have an extensive sarcoplasmic reticulum for the rapid release of calcium ions.  They play a major role in and are organized for endurance; have considerably more myoglobin and far more mitochondria than fast-twitch fibers. More myoglobin gives these fibers a red color. 
Anaerobic glycolysis predominates. Oxidative phosphorylation predominates
Less extensive blood supply around the muscle fibers because oxygen delivery is of secondary importance.  Extensive blood supply and more capillaries around the muscle fibers for more oxygen delivery.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida is in labor and it was noted that the action potentials of a single unit of myometrium caused the entire uterus to contract or relax simultaneously. This is possible due to the presence of which intercellular connections?
questions.solution:
The intercellular connections responsible for the myometrial cells causing the entire uterus to contract or relax simultaneously are gap junctions. During the time of labour, the number of these gap junctions is also increased under the influence of estrogen, thereby increasing the intensity of uterine contractility. 

Gap junctions are intercellular junctions that allow the passage of ions and smaller molecules between the cells. It permits rapid cell-to-cell spread of action potentials that provide for coordinated and smooth contraction. 

They are present in intercalated discs, uterus, urinary bladder, ureter, choroid plexus between the cells etc. The cells in these organs constitute a unit or syncytium containing thousands of smooth muscle fibres that contract together as a single unit. 

 Thus, the functions of gap junctions include - 
  • Passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, and other solutes with molecular weight up to about 1000 Da. It permits these substances to pass between the cells without entering the extracellular fluid. 
  • Provide both chemical and electrical coupling between cells. 

The structural unit present in the gap junctions is connexons, made of subunits called connexins. These connexons determine the permeability and selectivity of these junctions. 

Mutations of the connexin have predisposed to conditions like arteriosclerosis, myoclonic epilepsy, idiopathic atrial fibrillation, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (X-linked) etc. 

 

Other options - 

Option B: Tight junctions or zonula occludens are present around the apical margins of the cells in epithelia such as the intestinal mucosa, the walls of the renal tubules, and the choroid plexus. They have ridges, half from each cell which adheres so strongly that there is no space between the cells. These tight junctions permit the passage of ions, solutes, and intracellular signalling molecules in between adjacent cells via the paracellular pathway.

Option C: Hemidesmosomes attach cells to the underlying basal lamina and are connected intracellularly to intermediate filaments. They contain integrins.

Option D: Adherent junctions or zonula adherens is a continuous structure on the basal side of the zonula occludens. It contains cadherins.

questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of?
questions.solution:
A single neuron receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons is an example of convergence.

Convergence means signals from multiple inputs uniting to excite a single neuron. It can be of 2 types:

  • Convergence from a single source
  • Convergence from multiple sources

The importance of convergence is that neurons are almost never excited by an action potential from a single input terminal. However, action potentials converging on the neuron from multiple terminals provide enough spatial summation to bring the neuron to the threshold required for discharge.

Other options:

Options A and B: Type I and type II pneumocytes are seen in the alveolar epithelium. Type I cells are responsible for gas exchange whereas type II cells produce surfactants.

Option D: Kulchitsky cells are the neuroendocrine cells present in the bronchial mucosa of the lungs. These cells have neurosecretory-type granules and can release a variety of factors including serotonin, calcitonin, and gastrin-releasing peptide (bombesin).

questions.text: A researcher is studying the phases of the ventricular muscle action potential as shown below. Which phase represents the closing of fast sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Phase 1 represents the closure of fast sodium channels.

Phases of the cardiac muscle action potential:

Phase 0 (Depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels(voltage-gated sodium channels) open and cause sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reached about +20 mV and the sodium channels close. 

Phase 1 (Initial repolarization): Closing of fast sodium channels. The fast sodium channel close and the potassium channels open. the potassium ions leave the cell leading to repolarisation. 

Phase 2 (Plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The slowly opening voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening in phases 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in the efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 

Phase 3 (Rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to resting level. 

Phase 4 (Resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: Consider the following part of the neurological examination of a patient and choose the correct statement regarding it.

choices.text: The stretch receptor is present in series with the muscle fibre.
Sensitivity of the stretch receptor is lost when the muscle is contracting.
This reflex involves the activation of an inhibitory interneuron to the antagonistic muscle.
The stimulus for this reflex is the increased tension in the muscle.

questions.solution:
In the given picture the patient is being tested for the knee-jerk reflex (patellar reflex). It is an example of a deep tendon reflex or myotatic stretch reflex as stretching the muscle causes reflex contraction. During this reflex, there is an inhibition of the antagonistic muscles via an inhibitory interneuron. 

Any deep tendon reflex is mediated by muscle spindles. They respond to stretching of the muscle (option D) and correct the muscle length by causing contraction. They are composed of intrafusal muscle fibers and are arranged parallel to the extrafusal muscle fibers (option A). The intrafusal fibers consist of nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers. The sensory innervation to the muscle spindle is from type Ia (detect the velocity of length change) and type II (detect the length of the muscle fibers) nerve fibers. While Ia fibers innervate the central region of both nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers, type II fibers innervate only the nuclear chain fibers.

Activation of type Ia fiber stimulates the α motor neuron in the spinal cord and thus leads to contraction of the muscle fiber and a decrease in the length. γ motor fibers to the muscle spindle are co-activated so that the sensitivity of the muscle spindle remains the same even during the contraction of the extrafusal muscle fibers (option B). At the same time, an inhibitory interneuron to the antagonistic muscles is stimulated, to cause the relaxation of the antagonistic muscles and prevent overstretching. 
 
 

Clinical aspect: 

  • Brisk, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes are seen in upper motor neuron lesions affecting the descending spinal tracts like the corticospinal tract. 
  • Hypoactive or absent reflexes are seen in lower motor neuron lesions or lesions affecting the components of the reflex arc. Absent reflexes can be seen in diabetes, deep sleep, coma, nerve block and spinal anesthesia.
  • The pendular knee jerk, in which tapping the patellar tendon results in to-and-fro movements of the limb is seen in cerebellar lesions. The increased swinging occurs due to hypotonia of both flexors and extensors leading to a lack of restraint on each other.

questions.text: Which of the following molecular motors is mainly responsible for the ciliary movement?
questions.solution:
The interaction of the axonemal dynein with the microtubules is responsible for the ciliary movement.

Molecular motors are ATPases that move proteins, organelles, and other cellular components collectively referred to as 'cargo' to various parts of the cell. They convert the energy of ATP into movement along the cytoskeleton, taking their cargo with them. There are three superfamilies of molecular motors, which include dynein, kinesin and myosin.

Dyneins:

  • They have two heads, with their neckpieces embedded in a complex of proteins.
  • Cytoplasmic dyneins are similar to conventional kinesin, except they move particles and membranes to the minus (–) end of the microtubules.
  • Axonemal dyneins are present with the axonemes of the cilia. An axoneme consists of a unique arrangement of nine outer microtubule doublets and two inner microtubules ("9+2" arrangement). The coordinated dynein–microtubule interactions within the axoneme are responsible for the ciliary and sperm movement.

Kinesin:

  • The conventional form of kinesin is a double-headed molecule that moves its cargo toward the plus (“+”) ends of microtubules.
  • Some kinesins are associated with mitosis and meiosis.
  • Other kinesins perform different functions, and may also move cargo to the minus (“–”) end of microtubules.

Myosins:

  • There are about 18 classes of myosins.
  • The heads of some myosin molecules (myosin II) bind to actin and produce motion by bending their neck regions.
  • Some myosin molecules (myosin V) may move the cargo, by walking along microfilaments, one head after the other.

Other options:

Option C: Dynamin is a GTPase responsible for clathrin-mediated endocytosis.

questions.text: Administration of O2 has maximum benefit in:
questions.solution:
Administration of oxygen has maximum benefit in hypoxic hypoxia.

Hypoxic hypoxia refers to a condition in which there is low atmospheric Po2, leading to low arterial Po2. Hence, supplemental O2 can be very beneficial when the cause of hypoxia is due to limited oxygen availability.

Administration of oxygen-rich gas has limited value in anemic, histotoxic, and stagnant hypoxia because:

Anemic hypoxia- Oxygen delivery is not beneficial because despite increasing the exogenous oxygen delivery, an anemic person will not have the capacity to carry more oxygen due to the hemoglobin/ red blood cell deficit in anemia.

Histotoxic hypoxia- The most common example is cyanide poisoning. Cyanide inhibits important enzymes in the oxidative phosphorylation process, which is essential to the survival of our cells. Additional oxygen supplementation will not be able to overcome this inhibition, and so it will have limited benefit. Hyperbaric oxygen may be helpful to some extent.

Stagnant hypoxia- Stagnant hypoxia refers to ischemic hypoxia that results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock. In such conditions, administering intravenous fluids can improve the patient's condition because it is the circulation that is affected. If the shock is prolonged it can result in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which can be treated with positive pressure ventilation and not simply by increasing oxygen administration.

questions.text: As more fluid reaches the distal tubule of the kidney, the glomerular filtration in the same nephron will decrease. Which of the following is not a part of this feedback mechanism?
questions.solution:
The feedback mechanism in question is tubuloglomerular feedback. In response to increased fluid and Na+ delivery to the distal tubule, there will be mesangial cell relaxation to increase the filtration area and allow more Na+ to be filtered. 

Tubuloglomerular feedback is responsible for changing the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in response to the amount of fluid that reaches the distal tubule. The sensor for this response is the macula densa. The amount of sodium and chloride entering the macula densa cells is a proxy for the amount of fluid delivered to the distal tubule. Increased sodium delivery causes an increase in the activity of Na+, K+ ATPase and resulting ATP hydrolysis leads to the formation of more adenosine. This adenosine acts on adenosine A1 receptors on the macula densa cells to cause calcium release, which causes afferent arteriolar constriction. Increased sodium delivery to the distal tubule will also decrease the release of renin and consequently the formation of angiotensin II. This will finally result in mesangial cell relaxation. 

The GFR is proportional to the Kf (glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient), which depends on capillary permeability and the effective filtration surface area. The filtration surface area can be altered by the contraction or relaxation of the mesangial cells. Angiotensin II is an important factor causing mesangial cell contraction. This decreases the available surface area and the GFR. This causes less sodium to be filtered and more of it to be retained in the body, thus bringing the body fluid volume towards normal. 

Another mechanism that is responsible for the regulation of renal blood flow and GFR is the myogenic mechanism. When there is an excessive stretch of the renal vessel wall due to an increased amount of fluid, there is vascular smooth muscle contraction due to calcium entry. This prevents undue increases in renal blood flow and GFR when the arterial pressure is high.

questions.text: You prescribe oral rehydration solution (ORS) to a child brought to the outpatient department with complaints of loose stools. ORS facilitates glucose absorption through sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter-1 (SGLT-1). This glucose co-transport with sodium ions is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Glucose co-transported with sodium is an example of secondary active transport.

Transporting more than one substance together using a single transport protein against the gradient is known as secondary active transport. As one of the substances (e.g., sodium) diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, energy is released, which is used to drive another substance (e.g., glucose) against the gradient. Thus, secondary active transport does not require energy directly from ATP.
 
Sodium ions are transported out of cells by primary active transport, resulting in a large concentration gradient across the cell membrane. This gradient represents a storehouse of energy, which is used by sodium to pull glucose along with it using the SGLT-1 transporter. This phenomenon, called co- transport, is one form of secondary active transport. 

Types of transport:

  • Active transport
    • Primary
      • Energy is derived from ATP.
      • Example: Na+ K+ ATPase pump.
    • Secondary:
      • Energy is derived indirectly (ion gradient).
      • Example: Sodium linked glucose transport in kidneys and intestine, Sodium linked iodine transport
  • Passive transport
    • Simple:
      • No energy is required.
      • No carrier molecule is involved.
      • Eg. O2 exchange in alveoli.
    • Facilitated:
      • No energy is required.
      • Carrier molecule involved.
      • Eg. Glucose transport by GLUT transporters.

questions.text: Which of the following factors causes increased secretion of aldosterone?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia and activation of the renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion.

The following factors are known to affect the regulation of aldosterone: 

  • Hyperkalemia increases aldosterone secretion.
  • Increased angiotensin II concentration increases aldosterone secretion.
  • Hypernatremia slightly decreases aldosterone secretion.
  • ANP secreted by the heart, decreases aldosterone secretion
  • ACTH from the anterior pituitary gland is necessary for aldosterone secretion but has minimal effect in physiological conditions.

Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary.

Primary

  • Primary hyperaldosteronism occurs due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone, with resultant suppression of the renin-angiotensin system and decreased plasma renin activity.
  • Blood pressure elevation is the most common manifestation of primary hyperaldosteronism
  • Hypokalemia was considered a mandatory feature of primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • The diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity.
  • When primary hyperaldosteronism is caused by a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma, the condition is referred to as Conn syndrome. Aldosterone-producing adenomas show the presence of eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions, known as spironolactone bodies. These spironolactone bodies are found after treatment with the antihypertensive drug spironolactone.

Secondary hyperaldosteronism

  • Aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin system, and may be seen in cirrhosis, heart failure, and nephrosis.

questions.text: If voltage-gated potassium channels are blocked in the marked phase of the myocyte action potential, which of the following is the most likely result?

choices.text: Membrane potential will become more positive
Membrane potential will become more negative
Membrane potential will reach resting value

questions.solution:
The marked phase of the myocyte action potential is phase 2 or the plateau phase. Blocking the voltage-gated K+ channels during this phase would lead to the membrane potential becoming more positive. 

During the plateau phase of the myocyte action potential, the Ca2+ influx from the L-type Ca2+ channels balances out the K+ efflux through the voltage-gated K+ channel, and thus the membrane potential remains in a plateau. However, if the voltage-gated K+ channels are blocked during this phase, it would lead to the unopposed entry of Ca2+ into the cell, which will make the membrane potential more positive.

The phases in the myocyte action potential are as follows:

Phase 0: Depolarization occurs due to the opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels (fast sodium channels) and Na+ influx.

Phase 1: Initial repolarization occurs due to the closure of the inactivation gate of the Na+ channels and the opening up of K+ channels, leading to a net outward current. 

Phase 2: Plateau consists of relatively stable, depolarized membrane potential. During this phase, Ca2+ ions move into the cell because of the opening of L-type Ca2+ channels. This is balanced by the K+ ions moving out due to open K+ channels. This causes the membrane potential to remain at a stable depolarized value. The Ca2+ entry during the plateau phase potentiates the release of more Ca2+ from the intracellular stores for myocyte contraction. This is known as calcium-induced calcium release. 

Phase 3: Rapid repolarization occurs due to the closure of Ca2+ channels and K+ ions still moving out of the cell due to open K+ channels, leading to a net outward current. At the end of phase 3, the K+ current decreases because the membrane potential approaches the equilibrium potential of K+.

Phase 4: Resting membrane potential

questions.text: Transport of iron from enterocytes into the blood is done by which of the following proteins:
questions.solution:
Transport of iron from enterocytes into the blood is done by ferroportin.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron in our gut exists in 2 forms, they are non-heme and heme iron. Luminal non-heme iron is mostly in the Fe3+ (ferric) state and is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases. Fe2+ iron is then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

Given below is an image of iron absorption that shows divalent metal transporter-1 protein in intestinal mucosal cells.

Heme iron is moved across the apical membrane into the cytoplasm through heme transporters.

In the duodenal cells, Fe2+ iron can follow one of two pathways: transport to the blood or storage as mucosal iron. The nonstorage form of Fe2+ iron is transported from the cytoplasm into circulation by the protein ferroportin. A protein called hephaestin (Hp) is associated with ferroportin 1. It is not a transporter itself, but it facilitates basolateral transport

Once in circulation, Fe2+ is again oxidized back to Fe3+ iron by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The newly absorbed Fe3+ iron binds rapidly to transferrin, which delivers iron to red cell progenitors in the marrow.

Hepcidin is a protein secreted from the liver that plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate, it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby decreases iron absorption.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy sustained a wound in the forearm while playing on the ground. The wound was bleeding for some time and stopped after the formation of a blood clot. The type of homeostasis mechanism acting in this scenario is also seen in all the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the process of blood clotting which is an example of positive feedback. This is also seen in all the other conditions except pulmonary hyperventilation which is an example of negative feedback.

Pulmonary hyperventilation is a negative feedback mechanism where a stimulus (like increased CO2 in blood) leads to a response- pulmonary hyperventilation which reduces the original stimulus (blood CO2 level decreases) and brings back the system to its original state.

Positive feedback is the type of feedback in which the initial stimulus triggers a response that deviates further from the original state. Negative feedback is a system where the initial stimulus triggers a response that restores the original state. 

Most mechanisms in our body follow the negative feedback mechanism which helps to maintain homeostasis. For example, an increase in gastric acids leads to a decrease in gastric secretion.

Positive feedback is seen in a few conditions where a physiological process has to propagate itself. These include:

  • Childbirth
  • Blood clotting
  • LH surge
  • Action potential

Positive feedback may sometimes lead to vicious cycles, eg. shock.

The v-wave of the JVP waveform is responsible for the atrial filling during ventricular systole.

questions.text: Visual field testing of a patient revealed the following type of loss. Where is the likely site of lesion in optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The image shows homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The likely site of the lesion is occipital lobe.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

HH may be either complete or incomplete. 

  • A complete HH is characterised by loss of entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes.
  • An incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Incomplete HH is further classified as congruous or incongruous, depending on whether the extent of partial loss of visual field in both the eyes is same or different, respectively.

Lesions involving occipital lobe usually shows macular sparing because macular representation is seperate and quite large as compared to peripheral vision. Moreover, macular area in occipital lobe is supplied both by posterior and middle cerebral artery. In case of vascular lesions (eg stroke) affecting occipital lobe, it is less likely to involve both these arteries.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: During an experiment, it was found that a skeletal muscle's latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period were 15 ms, 30 ms, and 60 ms, respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency.
questions.solution:
The tetanizing frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 33 per second.

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period (per second)

Therefore, tetanizing frequency = 1/30 per millisecond = 1/0.03 per second = 1000/30 per second = 33 per second.

With repeated stimulation, contraction occurs repeatedly before any relaxation has occurred. This causes the individual responses to fuse into one continuous contraction. Such a response is called tetanus (tetanic contraction). ​​​Tetanizing frequency is the minimum frequency required for producing tetanus.

Tetanus is of two types, complete tetanus, when no relaxation occurs between stimuli, and incomplete tetanus, when periods of incomplete relaxation occur between the summated stimuli. 

When there is a repeated stimulus to a muscle fiber before relaxation, it produces an additional contraction of the muscle. The second contraction adds to the first contraction and the total strength of contraction increases. This phenomenon is known as a summation of contractions.

The given image shows a spirometer. Residual volume (RV) cannot be measured using this instrument. It also cannot measure any capacity that involves residual volume i.e., functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC).

Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lung after forceful expiration. As we cannot expire this air, it cannot be directly measured by spirometry.

To measure RV, we need to first measure FRC by the helium dilution technique and then calculate RV by subtracting expiratory reserve volume (ERV) from FRC.

RV = FRC - ERV

questions.text: A Physiologist while studying about thermoregulation in humans observed that the temperature regulatory responses are activated on reaching a threshold temperature for maintaining relatively uniform body temperature. Among the following options, which pair of regulatory response and its threshold temperature have been wrongly matched?
questions.solution:
Sweating is seen at 37°C and is associated with vasodilation for heat loss, not vasoconstriction.

Humans are homeothermic animals, hence despite being in either 40°C or -10°C, our core body temperature is close to normal range. To maintain the body temperature close to normal, various regulatory mechanisms come into action. These are seen as subtle responses like curling up in cooler weather and may lead to visible shivering on chilly nights. Similarly, on warm days we tend to increase our heat loss by sweating and vasodilation, making core heat easy to lose near the skin. These responses are activated on reaching a threshold temperature as given below:

  • 37°C - Sweating and vasodilation
  • 36.8°C - Vasoconstriction
  • 36°C - Non-shivering thermogenesis
  • 35°C - Shivering

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic male was brought to the emergency department in a semiconscious state with deep breaths. His RBG was 600 mg% and the Rothera's test was positive. Which of the following type of Oxygen-Hb dissociation curves is expected to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in the clinical scenario has been suffering from diabetic ketoacidosis. Hence, a shift to the right (D) of the ODC curve is expected in this patient.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shape.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favours O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen)

Shift to the right is caused by (Conditions with an increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilise O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2

Interpretation of the curves:

  • The curve marked 'A' is the ODC curve for myoglobin. It assumes the shape of a rectangular hyperbola.
  • The curve marked 'C' is the normal ODC curve and the curves 'B' and 'D' are the shift of the normal curve to left and right respectively.
